div.p: THE Counterfeits, A COMEDY, As it is Acted at the Duke's Theatre.
div.q: Vbi voluptas quaeritur, ibi non minus laudis promeretur qui pessimè dixit, quàm qui optimè, eò quòd non minùs delectet—
div.p: Licensed, Aug. 29. 1678. R. L'estrange.
LONDON, Printed for Iacob Tonson, at the Iudges-head in Chancery-lane. 1679.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.l: IT is the Fate of Strangers to the Town,
To have the Play and Prologue too their own:
Whilst Writers here for one another sweat,
Clubbing like Carr-men when a Brother's set.
Nay, dull insipid Farce you will commend
For sake of Prologue-writing gifted Friend;
Some gentle follower of the Wits, who thinks
He sucks in Poetry when-e're he drinks.
Since these have left no Formal So or Thus,
I'll bluntly tell you what you'll have from us.
Know then our Poet ventures more by far
Then all the blustering Hero's of the War.
For he without a Second does engage
Throngs of a fulsome bawdy scribing Age;
And dares in th' midst of cry'd-up Satyr vent
What you'll acknowledge nicely innocent.
'Tis bold and new, and 'mongst the ruffling Toys,
Whose Wit is beastly Impudence and Noise,
He knows he's damn'd; but wou'd be so on choice.
Ladies, for you he writ, much griev'd to see
Your best of Pleasures, harmless Comedy,
Made Bawd to such mean durty Ribaldry
As scarce is known to th' Offall of the Gallery.
Shou'd he miscarry, 'tis in such a Cause
Will challenge Pardon, if not gain Applause.
Be kind, he's young, and on your hands may mend.
'Tis something so to write as not t'offend.

div.head: ACT I. SCENE 1. The High Street in Madrid.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: SHe is your Sister, Antonio.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: That's it that makes my Hell: were she as far from my Bloud, as now my Love, she might, if possible, out-sin her Sex, and never injure me. But to call me Brother, and be pointed at for Whore, Carlos; were the Lives of all our Family twisted up in hers, nay, should all Posterity perish with her, she dies.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: This Passion puts thee beyond all Counsel: prithee be thy self, and let me hear the Circumstances of your Story. I am too much a Spaniard, not to prompt you to Revenge; but would first know why, and how.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Believe me, thou art blest, Carlos, who hast none of this frail Tribe so near thy Bloud, to rack thy Thoughts. The very Being of the Sex is infectious, and from the moment of their Birth corrupts their Bloud, and leaves them all a Stain.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: This is Raving past hopes of Cure.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Would you have me tame, when all my Care and future● Hopes are at once blasted? Had I not Fondness for her beyond that of Mothers? Fool that I was, to trust my Happiness on the treacherous prop● of a Woman's Faith!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: This may still be Jealousie, and founded on the hate of some sly Informer.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Would my Life could buy the least show for Doubt. No, see, see Carlos, her own Hand witnesses against her self; the onely thing wherein a Woman ought to be believ'd.

body.p: — Vitelli, a Gentleman of Cordova, as he pretended, with promise of Marriage● had possession of my Bed● and, as I am inform'd, is fled towards Castile. My Retreat is to a Monastery, where, you shall know when my Injuries are reveng'd—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Dost thou not find her more impudent then practis'd Bauds? Had he still staid to feed her Lustful flame, I had been ignorant.
Yes, you shall be reveng'd on your Vitelli; and with the same Dagger, though thou wert professing at the Altar, I'd send thee to keep company with the Devils like thy self.
Carlos, thou must not trust thy very Thoughts with this Secret. Is there not something in my Looks may tell the world my Sister's Whore? Hah—

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: This is Madness beyond Bedlam; be calm, and I'll further your Design.— But—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Each Minute's now an Age; but once reveng'd, thou shalt see me calm as sleeping Children. I was not wont to be thus.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Nor must you be, Antonio; this Passion is a certain Hinderance to your purpose. How can I assist you, when you will not give your self time to tell your Story?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: True, Carlos, and thou hast nam'd the onely thing could teach me Patience to relate my Shame. Know then, that very night I had concluded the advantageous Match for this false Woman, with Don Alonso Fonseca, the great Heir, returning late home, brisk with wine, and over-joy'd at the Success, I entred at the Garden-door, which I found open, and all the House silent as Death. Fear of my greatest Treasure wing'd me to her Chamber: where, to my perpetual Torment, I found that Letter. Oh Carlos! canst thou guess the Sighs of Merchants in a Storm, or utmost Pangs of Parents o're their dying Hopes? such was my Treasure, such my Loss and Grief.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: The Surprize must needs be great, and the unlucky Circumstances adde much to the Affliction. But what Account could your Servants give?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: All I could learn was, that she (who you know always govern'd) commanded them to bed, and that her Maid should wait my coming home; by which means, unknown to any, they escap'd.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Know you the place of her Retirement she speaks of?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
No, I left her Shame to be her Punishment, till I could wreak
my Vengeance on Vitelli, who I judge would chuse Madrid, (for of Cordova he is not,) both for the Solemnity, and likeliest place to lie conceal'd.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Do you know him?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: No, Carlos, but such an Action must leave some mark upon the base Offender; and something tells me, my heightned Rage will point me to the curst Ruiner of my Honour.— Methinks I must look him dead.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Our Friendship needs not be confirm'd by Talking; Antonio knows how much Carlos would doe to serve him. Nor will I spend a Minute otherwise then in his Search. Unload thy self, and let me bear half the weight. Thou hast too much Love, and too much sense of Honour.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Carlos, thou knew'st my Father well: methinks I see him just now breathing out his last, and with his cold trembling hand delivering up Elvira to my Care. Take her, said he, Antonio, the Treasure of my life, the Darling of thy lost Mother: and as thou hopest to meet us both in Heaven, swear never to marry till thou hast settled her. I swore; and when I would have added more, he onely answered with a Smile, and seem'd to die o'rejoy'd.
sp.l: Blest man! how unsuccessful was thy Care!
And 'twas to perjure me thou mad'st me swear.
We Interest and Honour urge in vain,
Where Lust and Passion absolute do reign. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE 2. A Chamber in the Inn.
div.stage: Elvira, Clara, in mens Apparel: Elvira like a Knight of Malta.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: ARe we alone, Clara? each step I take I feel a Dagger at my heart. Wretched Woman, how am I fall'n! Oh the blest time, when innocently we spent our days in pitying the rest of our frail Sex! Am● I not a Monster branded for my Infamy? Slave that I was to perjur'd false Vitelli!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: For Heaven's sake, Madam, don't weary me with Complaints. I swear the long-ear'd Devil I rid has laid me up this month. I fansied my self flying, when I whipt and spurr'd. They may laugh at Scholars, Tailours and Seamen; but if a Chamber-maid in Breeches don't ride with the wor●● of 'em, I'll sell my Maidenhead for four Grapes, and they are cheap in this Country.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p:
Thou art still all Mirth: but sooner shall the Sun rest, then I live and not seek the false Vitelli. Base, cruel man, to leave his poor Elvira
so! Oh! I could curse him, would my Heart give leave; but that belies my Tongue.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Well, Madam, you know Clara is no Flincher; but I'd sooner undertake to know a Bee amongst a Swarm, then find out a Man in this Crowd whose Name you're as uncertain of, as you are certain of his Dishonesty. This Will-of-the-wisp of Love wants Wit as well as Eyes. Aside.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I've often heard him say, (and sure all he said could not be false,) that his Attendance upon the Council of State would be necessary towards the recovery of an Inheritance; so that I conclude him here: and were he amongst millions, I have too much reason not to know him.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: The truth is, you have been pretty intimately acquainted. Aside. Not to fright you, Madam, but prepare you for the worst; (though the truth is, we Women seldom fail at a pinch) what if your Brother should come to the Celebration of the Royal Marriage, and find us here? how would you avoid a certain Ruine?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: It will be impossible for him to make me more wretched. But 'midst this Concourse, thus disguis'd, it will not be easie for to meet, much less to know us. Let what will come, I am too miserable to fear a Danger, and onely wander to find variety of Torments.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Nay, good Madam, no more Whining. 'Slid, did I knight you for this? or will a few driveling Tears find your Lover, and escape your Brother's Fury? Think how ill Sniveling becomes a pair of Breeches. Could I ever mistrust that You, that had the courage to leave your House and Country to turn Knight-Errant, nay more, plainly tell your Brother by your Letter, you had yielded up your Fort to a strange Cavalier, should come to talk of Danger and Wretched; things fit for Boys thoughts and Womens fears, not for Knights of Malta?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Thy Innocence maintains thy Mirth: but what can wrong'd Elvira doe, weigh'd down by a vast load of Shame, that sinks my very Soul?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: There's your little impertinent Nicety, to call that Shame, Women spend their lives to purchase. Why, there's not one in hundreds that you meet, that seem devout and melancholick, but are contriving to throw away that Toy you wot of: and 'tis the first Lesson their Mothers teach them, to lose it handsomely.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: But that I know this design'd to divert my Cares, thou wert past hope of Pardon.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Heaven knows how dear I pay for all this Mirth. Aside. Pardon, Madam, (Sir, I should have said) I expect none, whilst I am in the right.

'Faith, methinks this Cross becomes you. Was't gain'd by some strange Atchievement against the Musselmen? or is it for fear the Women should run mad of such Sweetness, that you put this Cross over your Plague-door? Truth is, there may be danger of Swelling for those come near it.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I shall lose all Patience, and wish you miserable as my self, if you persist in this Idleness.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: That's pleasant● you'd perswade me you're Woman toothsome, Sir, 'tis not that Cross shall bear you harmless. I know a Vow may be broke to save a Maid's longing. Oh my heart! whither do I ramble? Aside.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: All thy Counterfeit cannot raise me to a Smile. Alas● it is already broke. But that fond Fool dares trust a man, though heightn'd with such Vows as would make the most perjur'd tremble, is deservedly lost. Credulous, rash, doating, sottish Woman! didst thou not know him Man? how couldst thou think him then to be believ'd?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Base that he was, to affront a person of your Honour, one that wears a Sword, and knows what's what. Did he refuse me, to meet me in the said Field provided at all points, I'd post him Coward, and hire Slaves to kick him.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Ah Clara! hadst thou but seen his pale and ghastly Looks, but heard his Sighs and Vows. Then would he kneel, and weep, and press my Hand; then rise, and swear again with such dreadfull Imprecations, nothing that was Woman could resist. I'm sure I did not; false to my self and too-too-loving Brother. Would I had ne'r been Woman: nor would I yet be Man, for I should be still far worse, and still more false. Yet would I were any thing but what I am.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I'm like to have a blest time on't; and all this for the loss of a Maidenhead. 'Faith it scares me so, if there be ever a Receipt in Spain to keep one, 't shall be the first thing I'll purchase: but I'm afraid 'tis very dear, and hard to come by.
Oh here's my Landlord: never man came in better time.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: You re welcome, Gentlemen; I hope your Lodgings please you.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Very well, Landlord, we are quickly pleas'd, so they be private. But I fear you'll be crowded against this great Solemnity.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Nothing can disturb you, the House is large, and this the most retir'd part.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: What other Strangers have you?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Yet onely one Gentleman and your selves.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Do you know from whence he came?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: No, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Prithee, Landlord, see our Dinner be made ready, and our Wine good and well cool'd: as hot as the weather is, I must have one Health to the Royal Pair.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sir, a Gentleman just now alighted calls for you.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I'm coming. Your Dinner shall be ready with all expedition.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: In the mean time we'll take a turn in the Yard, and see this New-comer.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I'm glad you have so much Woman in your Passion, as to be able to dissemble before Strangers.
Come, Sir, be brisk and gay, strut like a young Knight new dubb'd. So, that becomes you, and is tempting.
sp.l: Though the Men false and cruel you may find,
You yet may conquer all the Woman-kind. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE 3. The Inn-Yard.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: WIll you please to see your Chamber?

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: Not yet; I'll stay here a while for my Servants that are coming.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Are they much behind?

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: I guess, not; for coming early this morning from Iyescas, my man left my Portmantue behind him, and brought in stead of it a Stranger's that supt with me. But before we had got a league from thence, we found the Errour, and I sent them both back to change it. I hope they may speed, for the Gentleman was not stirring when we set out.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Is he coming this way, Sir?

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: No, he came from hence.
[Within Tonto.] Hostler, take in our Mules, and get 'em some fresh Straw.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: 'Tis like these are those you expect.

div.stage: Enter Tonto and Crispin with a Portmantue.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Never tell me, he must ride upon some Devil bridled and saddled.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.p: Would he would take him into his possession then; he has brought us into a fine condition.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: ‛ St, there's my Master. Well, Tonto, that hanging Look of thine always foretold ill.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: Have you brought back the right?

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.p: No, Sir, one much lighter in its stead.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: Curse on you both, Slaves! I am utterly ruin'd, without hopes lost● Why did you not pursue him? Dogs!

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Whither, Sir?

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: To Valentia, Rascals.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.p: Why, Sir, he was no more going to Valentia then you back to the Indies; but, as a Shepherd told us, took the upper way hither. Some Robber, Sir, on a Gennet got by the Wind: had he strid any thing else, we must have reach'd the Town before him.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: Careless Slaves! your Lives shall be some little Recompence.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, this were a Punishment too great, and most unworthy of your Sword.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: 'Twas not our fault: your coming out so early occasion'd the Mistake.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: Dog! but mutter towards an Excuse, and I'll silence thee for ever.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, give me leave to advise: 'tis not your Passion will recover what is lost; rather think which way you may retrieve it.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: If he be once hous'd in Town, 'twill be as difficult to find him, as an Honest woman in an Embassadour's Liberties. Your onely way will be, to send to watch his coming: 'tis likely he's yet upon the Road.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: Thanks, Gentlemen— Tonto and you go several ways; and if you hope for Pardon, bring some tidings of him.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Here, Landlord, take care of this. Exeunt Ton. Crisp.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Your Loss must certainly be great, that makes you thus concern'd.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: There was in it to the value of twelve thousand Ducats in Gold and Jewels.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: A Loss sufficient to undoe a Banquer.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: This is a course Welcome to Madrid.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: We cannot blame your Passion, caus'd by such a Misfortune.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: The Wealth is much below my care, could I but recover some Papers, which I would redeem with twice the sum.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: They needs must be of great import, to merit such a Ransome, and of too near concern to admit a Stranger's inquiry.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: No, Sir, that Cross you wear declares your obligation of succouring the Distrest: and if you will so much relieve my Sorrow, as to hear my Story, I would beg your Company in my Chamber.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I willingly shall wait you, Sir, and beg you will not scruple to admit my Friend.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: No, Sir; two such Counsellours may in some measure ease my Grief, and prove necessary to one so much a Stranger in this Court and Kingdom.— Landlord, shew a Room.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: [To Dor.] Don Luis desires to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Take this, and shew the best Chamber. Gives him the Portmantue. I'll wait you immediately, Gentlemen.

div.stage: Exeunt all but Dormilon. To him enter Don Luis.

sp.speaker: Luis.
sp.p: How fares my honest Friend Senior Dormilon?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Ever ready to serve the noble Don Luis.

sp.speaker: Luis.
sp.p: Have you any news yet of my Nephew Peralta?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: None, Sir: for though I cannot pretend to know him by his Face; I should soon guess him by his Discourse, were he amongst my Strangers.

sp.speaker: Luis.
sp.p: He has orders to trust himself to your care. I my self should scarce be able to challenge him by his Looks, it being thirteen years since he left Madrid for Flanders.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: His killing the Ensign was unlucky; especially in this nick of time, whilst it deprives him of so fair an Estate as his Brother has left him.

sp.speaker: Luis.
sp.p: I'll venture mine to procure his Pardon, and make a Composition with the Widow; which I do not much doubt of, if he escapes those that watch his coming into the Town.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Her knowing of his coming is strange.

sp.speaker: Luis.
sp.p: 'Tis certain, and that she has so far prevail'd with the Corrigidor, that he has commanded all his Alguazills to apprehend him, if possible, at his arrival. Which is the reason I wrote him word to Valentia, where he has lain conceal'd, to come to your House first; mine being continually beset ever since he left Flanders.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: As soon as he comes, you shall have notice; and here he shall be safe as in S. Isidor's Church.

sp.speaker: Luis.
sp.p: Senior, I thank you. I am now going to meet the Widow at the Palace about the Reconcilement, judging much easier to buy her off before he is in Custody.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Fortune attend you, Sir. Money is a prevailing Advocate.

sp.speaker: Luis.
sp.p: When that once fails, we must submit to Fate.

div.head: SCENE 4. Vitelli's Chamber.
div.stage: Vitelli, Elvira, Clara; Boy with the Portmantue.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: BOy, leave us. Exit Boy.

Sir, I am descended of the ancient Family of the Vitelli from whence I took my name. My Father, of no mean Fortune, has long since contracted a strict Friendship with one Don Gomez Aranda; and here in Madrid liv'd with greatest expressions of mutual Love. At last forc'd to part, Don Gomez set up his Residence in this Court; and my Father past the Seas to Mexico, where he has ever since been: and I in that great City of the New World first saw Light.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Was you never, Sir, in Spain till now?

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: Never: And the Occasion of my coming is to consummate a Match (formerly agreed on by our Fathers, that this way they might seal and propagate their Friendship) between the onely Daughter of Don Gomez and my self. The Painter makes me believe her fair and charming, and I arrived with all the Expectation of a longing Bridegroom; but after a long Voiage find my self wreck'd on Shore.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Your Loss can be no hindrance to this Affair.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: Yes, much; my Letters are all gone I brought her Father from my own; and I have no reason he should believe me on my bare Word, without farther Evidence to confirm him.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Does he expect you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: That he hath done these six months.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: He cannot doubt the truth of your Relation; or at least will so long suspend, till you can send to Cadiz, where I suppose you landed, and give him farther Testimony of being what you say you are.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: Your Counsel cannot be disputed; I'll immediately go seek him out.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I should think it well advised to open this Portmantue; 'tis possible it may discover who has put the Change upon you.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: If any thing can be thought true a Villain says, he's called Vitelli. 'Twas our being of the same Name that began this unfortunate Acquaintance. But this I hope will evidence the contrary. 'Twould adde to my Affliction, to have a Rascal justly claim the Name of my Family.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Would to Heaven I'd been a Stranger to that fatal Name, that like a Plague infects the air 'tis mention'd in.

div.stage: Vitelli breaks open the Portmantue, and Clara helping him empty it, among other things finds some Letters, and Elvira ' s Picture.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Heavens! what's here? a Broker's Shop?

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: There can be nothing worth the search amongst such Rags.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: See, Sir, here are Papers, and a Lady's Picture.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: A Moor to my Goddess; throw the Trifle by.

div.stage: While he looks on the Papers, Clara knows the Picture to be her Lady's, and shews it her.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Do you know this, Madam?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Oh my Heart! the very same I gave the false Vitelli.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Never whine, but remember you are a Woman, and to dissemble, or all is ruin'd. We must be nigh a Discovery. Aside from Vitelli.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: The Trial is too great.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: You seem concern'd; does that Picture cause it?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I was saying, Sir, there is something in this Look that seems strangely unfortunate.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: And I, that the Eyes had such a yielding Easiness, as might be betray'd by false Vows: and that here me thought the Painter had exprest such a languishing Cast as spoke the height of Love.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: 'Faith, Sir, I am not curious; but may pronounce the Lady miserable enough has fallen into the hands of this Ruiner of my Fortunes.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Did the Beauty you adore much exceed this?

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: As this an Indian; her very Figure was enough to make all men love, and its Loss to make all men die.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: This is not so despicable a Face, that a Lover ought to be asham'd of Constancy. Sure I am, as bad a one has oft been sigh'd for.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: By some fond Fools that never knew a Beauty; but this is all Cloud to my Brightness.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: This will come to a Quarrel if not prevented. The disparaging a Woman's Beauty turns the tamest of the Sex to a Scold.
Pray, Sir, what Papers are those? this seems much from your Design.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: True, but entred on the discourse of one I love, I lose my self and Business. They are Letters. This to the most excellent Duke of Ossuna; this to the Regent of the Council of Aragon; this to the Marquis of Velada.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: By these he should be a man of Fortune and Repute, and not a Robber.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: The best way is to open one, 'tis probable you will find his Name and Quality.

body.p: The Bearer of this is Don Manuel Peralta, Captain-Lieutenant of my Regiment, who for killing an Ensign on the Guard (though highly provok'd) is compell'd to leave this Place, to prevent the Governour's Severity; and flies to your Lordship's Protection, by whose favour I doubt not he will obtain a Pardon, which I earnestly desire; as that of your Lordship for this Trouble given you by,

closer.signed: Your Lordship's most humble Servant and Kinsman, the Earl of Pontilliana.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: This has made all plain: the onely means is, to have present recourse to the Marquis, declare your Loss, and beg his Assistance in the Recovery.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: 'Twould require Haste, lest he prevent you with some new Cheat.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: I fly, and something like Hope gives me a good Omen.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: We shall wait your Return with impatience.
Sure I am, my Happiness depends upon your Success. Exit Vitelli.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: What do you think of Vitelli now, Madam? Peralta I should say. You see he steals other things besides Maidenheads.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: But nothing of such Value, or so much past recovery.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: 'Faith, Madam, were that all, ' twer● nothing. For my part, I think the Principal well sunk, so one can secure the Use: troth is, to lose that too, is something no Woman can well bear.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Nothing but thy known Fidelity could secure thee from my Anger.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
What? I warrant you'd be grave, and thinking again; Oh the fine Gentleman upon his Gennet! how gracefully he bow'd! the tempting Serenades, passionate Letters, Complements beyond resistance; and when possest, all over Pleasure! and then he kist, and
vow'd, and left me full of Hopes, that equall'd all but present Joys.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: But disappointed, makes all Plagues and Death a Blessing. And 'tis from these Thoughts the wretched Elvira falls to be a Lump of black Despair.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: By my faith, this is pleasant: neither well full nor fasting. All the way we came; Oh Clara, were it possible, nay did I but think it so, e're to see him, thou shouldst find me chearfull as in my Innocence: Now 'tis more then probable we shall see him; The Trial is too great, and I'm a Lump of black Despair. Believe me, Madam, 'tis unnatural for a Woman to fear in extremity.
sp.l: Though Men with Counsel and with grave Debate,
May better War, and judge Intrigues of State;
In Exigences We the Rule have got.
No Woman e're could want Excuse or Plot. Exeunt.

div.trailer: The End of the First ACT.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: THis Master of mine is as unaccountable as a breaking Merchant. To steal from Valentia through ways scarce known to a Foot-pad; alight at the Town's end just a noon, when the Heat makes the Streets emptiest, to avoid being snapt by the Officers; and yet at the sight of the first Vail, forget all Dangers, and think himself as secure as a Confessour in a Church.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Now I am confirm'd 'tis he. For Heaven's sake, Madam, to your Chamber; 'tis downright Madness to make a double Venture.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
Certainly when the Devil would show his Master-piece, he puts on a Petticoat; and when he is not at leisure, a Woman may save him
the labour, and supply his place. [Sees Clara.] Here's a fit Vermin to be trapt, a smug Youth, that the Trail of a Wench may lead as far as a Fox a pack of Hounds.
[To her.] 'Tis a merry world with you, Senior.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Troth, Sir, he that can be sad with good Cloaths on his back, Money in his purse, and his Mistress Smiles, may he be condemn'd to the Gallies till he laugh.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: To curse him home, may he meet with such a Master as I have; and if he never laugh till he give him cause, I'm sure he must die a Slave.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Is your's such a Turk?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Oh! the Great Turk, Sir; and has by much a larger Seraglio: for all the use he makes of the whole World is to keep his Wenches on't.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Pray how do you call your Hercules?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Since you will have it so, Hercules Vitelli.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: With what confidence the Rogue lies! Aside.
By his Name he should be of a great Family.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: I am not Herald enough to know the greatness of his Ancestours, but to my knowledge his Issue is large; about as numerous as the Iews, and o' my conscience as much disperst.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I have an Acquaintance here, a Knight of Malta, that would make a rare Companion for him.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: A Knight of Malta? if he loves his Life, let him avoid him, for he has vow'd Destruction to all Pretenders to Chastity. You'll scarce believe it, but the sight of a Nun through a Grate, though he thinks her chast upon force, puts him into an Agony.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: You are much deceiv'd, Sir, a Knight's Vow is but what forbids the chast use of Marriage, and leaves him at liberty to all the world besides.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Nay, if he has a new way of interpreting his Oath, it may be they may fadge.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Methinks—

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: No more, I beseech you, Sir, I expect him each minute; and if I have not provided a Room before his coming, shall pay for this Prating.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I lodge in this House, and when you are at leisure shall be glad of more of your company.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Adieu, Senior.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Poor Elvira, a Town-bull would have prov'd as constant a Lover. Aside.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: A Chamber, Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Will you please to walk this way? I'll carry your Portmantue, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: No, Sirrah, I had a wise Father, that taught me to trust my self: by the Weight there may be the Indies in't.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I Do confess, Madam, I have been Cock of the brisk Fools, that set up for Wits with railing against Love. But I now recant; and my Pain has been so exquisite, since I had the honour to see you, that it may equal years of Sighs and Verses.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: I should not sooner know a practis'd Beggar by his Cant, then I do you for a formal repeating Woer; one that takes notes from Plays, practises with his Glass, and concludes the next Woman he meets will be fond of studied Nonsense.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: 'Tis barbarous to murther him with Wit, who has already yielded to your Beauty; the Power of which you know too great to suffer a Dissembler.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Sure you think me Daughter to the Knight of the Sun; or my Beauty could never warm through this Cloud.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: It does not extinguish the Fire, Madam, to hide the Flame that kindled it, that still burns and consumes.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: That's in the road again: could we but perswade you Gallants to forswear Fire, Sun, Flame and Fate, you would court with as much Silence as the Turk's Attendants wait.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: You shall bind me to any thing, so you will reward my Diligence, and understand by Signs.—
sp.stage: He courts her with affected Gestures and Signs.
sp.p: Let these then speak for me.—

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: A pretty Puppet-show, which when I am best at leisure, it may be I may throw away some few Rials to see again. Now I'm in haste. Violante runs out.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p:
Nay, ' saith, though your light Frigat hath gain'd the Port,
I'll make bold to seize the Tender, till I know of what Country you are.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: You'll find a smart Resistance. She struggles again.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Now you're mine; but some kind Answers to half a dozen Questions frees you. [Struggles still.] Come, 'tis but what thourt bound to by thy Place.— Your Mistresse's Name, and where she lives: Quickly, quickly; thou'lt be turn'd away for letting her lose a Gallant.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Sure you think your self in the Suburbs, or Embassadours Liberties, to take this freedom. I'd have you to know my Place is what's honest and honourable.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: And shall be so still for me, dear little Fury! But canst thou doe any thing more honourable then to promote an honest Love? Is it not pity a Gentleman should be ruin'd for want of two Words? a Charity your Sex is seldom sparing in.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I so perfectly hate you, I would lose that pleasure of Talking, did I not know, (if you are truly in Love, which Heaven grant!) what I have to say will rid the world of you. Learn and despair then. This Lady is just now to be married. Who she is, you shall ne'r be told, that you may die for an unknown Mistress, and make the better subject for a Ballad.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Truth is, this Anger does become thee; but for variety, and to shew the rest of your good Qualities, put on a relenting Look, and discover.— Thou art out of thy Calling to pretend to Secrecy.— By this thou shalt be kind.— [Gives her gold.] Though you design to make me Miserable, I know you will not make me a Forsworn wretch.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: You shew so noble a Constancy, that if I were to die, I can't forbear now. Oh, my Lady were a happy woman, could she hope for such a Lover. I vow, Sir, I did but try you; and I'll assure you, in my eye you are the properest, most accomplish'd Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Now thou flatterest; I can ne'r reward such Kindness— Prithee on.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: In short, Sir, for I shall be mist,

Her Name is Donna Violante, sole Daughter to Don Gomez Aranda, who lives in this House. What will make your Pretences fruitless is, her Quality, and that she is already contracted to a Gentleman she never saw, and whom she every moment expects from India.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: 'Tis ill, but not desperate, if you promise your Assistance.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: As far as I can serve you without endangering her Honour, and my own Honesty, which I'll assure you, Sir, I stand upon, you have made me yours. Exit Flora.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: This is one of the true Breed: some few that prove otherwise are of another Species. You may as well call a Wolf a Lamb, as her Woman that waits, and can keep a Secret, or resist a Bribe.— Well, the Devil does owe me a Spite, and has taken an opportunity of paying it. Certain it is, this Woman must be had; but how, I fear's a Question will ne'r be answered. Exit.

div.head: SCENE 3. Peralta's Chamber in the Inn.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: I Have a true Mule's life, Burthen and Provender. He was certainly bewitcht that first debas'd himself to Serve: but the downright Devil was in him that chose a Wencher for his Master. The wandring Iew is a staid House-keeper to him: 'tis odds but the next Petticoat he meets carries him for Turky ● and there he may take a fresh one for the Indies. I have often wondred at two things; one, what this Master of mine is made of: to my knowledge he has given away and lost more Hearts then our Kings have sent to people the New World; and yet o' my conscience he has such a stock left, that were they well marshall'd, they might fight the French King this next Campaign. T'other is, what could possess me to be Shadow to this termagant Turk, whose onely Religion is to conquer Women. Why should not Don Fabio sound as well as Don Peralta? I'm sure Historians impose upon us, or else the Family of the Fabii have been famous. And shall be agen, good Don Fabio.— Don Fabio. I have the advantage in the sound of my Roman Fore-fathers. Beso ' osté las manos.— muy criado de su merced. Excellent! now will I walk in as much state as a Grandeé, and with the Wisedom of a Privy-councellour: and when Affairs of State prove too heavy for me, my Boy and Musician shall divert me with a Song. But in the mean time, till my Retinue is settled, I will vouchsafe to be Boy and Musician to my self.

lg.head: SINGS.
lg.l: The names of Man and Master is a Chea●●
'Tis Dog-like to be rated here and there.
I will resolve, and shall be Great.
I set my self at Liberty:
'Tis onely Law that makes us Slaves;
Law first obey'd by Fools, and made by Knaves.
He that will be a Don,
He that will not his Freedom restore,
Was got by a Jew, and nurst by a Moor.

sp.p:
Humh! what a nick of time does this Master of mine chuse! Now do I see the Don running from before my Name, and leave poor Fabio to shift for himself; and feel all my Privy-councellourship trill down to my very Heels. But Fate still takes pleasure to baffle vast Designs.
Thus when the Wheel of Fortune turns,
Oh Spain, thy great Escurial burns.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: What Company's in the House?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: None of note that I hear of, but a Knight of Malta.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Where's my Landlord, Senior Dormilon?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Abroad, otherwise I had acquainted him with your being here.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: 'Tis lucky that you mist him, for I must yet be conceal'd; therefore on your life dissemble my true Name.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: So, the Devil and my Master have been juggling on some new Design. Aside.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: The great Hazard that I run is, lest my Portmantue should betray me. Where is that was left in its stead? That may discover who made the Exchange, and contribute to its recovery.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Here, Sir, may the Worth answer its Weight, and I can't be less then Don for the lucky Mistake. Fabio opens the Portmantue.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Open and search it. What's there?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Why, Gold and Jewells, Sir, without count. The Gentleman has paid dear for an old Suit and dern'd Linnen, and some few Bills that should have been discharg'd. Here are Letters too—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: How's this? To Don Gomez de Aranda? the Father of my ador'd Violante; and this no doubt the Indian they expect.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: A Lady's Picture, Sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: The same: By Heaven her Picture too! Hah! Why am not I then the true Vitelli? for that's the Name. I well remember began our Acquaintance; and that he told me the hopes of a fair Wife brought him to Spain. He that loves can't want Impudence, and these Evidences must stand the nicest Search. 'Tis resolv'd.— Put all up again, and make it fast.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: I think you resolve well● this Country's hot● and Company troublesome. Besides, you're used to Flanders. The Mules shall be ready, Sir; Gold's no Burthen.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: What's that you mutter, Rascal?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
A Journey, Sir, would be necessary, and healthfull● this Crowd
may breed the Plague. To be plain, let me beg of you to fly with this Treasure. In a short time you may purchase your Pardon in spight of this dissembling Widow, and never trouble your Friends to petition for't; and in the mean while, by the strength of this live as Great as the Governour.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: No, Villain, I have Business of greater consequence in hand; and when that's done, will return it to the Owner. Mean-spirited Rascal, to guess I would enrich my self by such base means!

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Will you but wink till I run, Sir? I have ventur'd Hanging in your Service e're this for six Olivers a day, with the Appurtenances of Poor-Jack and Bisket.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: No more, Slave; make it up, I say.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: And the Picture too?—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: That I shall have occasion for.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Here's one Doblon, Sir, I am strangely smitten with. May not I have that for Contemplation?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Not a Rial, Dog; take it up and follow me. And know from this time forward I am Vitelli, lately arrived from Mexico, and that you are now come with me from Cadiz. And upon these hints improve thy faculty of Lying. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Yes, I am an Indian, and am forc'd to value Gold at as little rate as those Fools. A pox of Honour and Honesty, 'tis as impertinent to a man and troublesome as a Maidenhead at fifteen, and as necessary to be parted with at the first good occasion. Exit with the Portmantue.

div.head: SCENE 4. A Parlour in Gomez house.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: HOw could I doe less, when I had taken the retaining Fee? Besides, Madam, he spoke with such a prevailing Earnestness, that I, that never had an aversion to a proper Gentleman, could not help it.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: A proper Gentleman! one of the forward pretending Fops, that have half a dozen fine things to say, and when they are done, prove as dull as an outworn Poet.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: This Railing with us Women is as certain a sign of Love, as Huffing with the Men, of Cowardise.— But it shall go hard or I'll find it. [Aside.]— In earnest, Madam, the Gallant dresses well. Did you mind his Freedom and courtly Mean?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p:
Dresses well? so does a Tailour's Prentice: and what you call
Freedom is onely Impudence pickt up by keeping Ill company; such sort of Wit as a man of sense takes more care to avoid, then such Triflers do to con it.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: This confirms me.—
You'll allow his Person manly and agreeable?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: I confess I have seen some few in a Crowd less desirable: but put him altogether, he's one of the last men I should chuse.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: You may be perswaded to see him again for all this Aversion.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Yes, if you can assure me I may doe him a Mischief by ir.— I wish I had never seen him— Aside.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Since you are so nice, I hope your Mexican will prove one made of Wax, without a Fault or Blemish.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: You're always disturbing me with things I hate. I tell you, I will have nothing to doe with Mankind either of the Old or New world. But of all things never name this Stranger more.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I hope I may rally a little on him, for that I design'd at first, onely I fear'd it might offend you. I'll try you this way.— Aside.

By my troth, Madam, I wisht you with me, for certainly never any thing was so worth laughing at. Besides what he said to you, he has not Language enough to ask what's a clock, or commend a Suit of Linnen. 'Tis as raw a Fool as ever came out of a Nursery.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Thou art always in extreams; I could not perceive so much Simpleness: I should have guess'd he had been a little at least conversant with the World.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Right.— No, believe me, Madam, he sneakt like a Boy before a Mother-in-law; and I am apt to think we are the first Women he ever adventured to speak to, and he threw me this Purse meerly for fear I should have jeared him. I was about teaching him to hold up his Head, and make a Leg● but the● he ran fort.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: This is impossible; all he said to me was consistent and courtly, his Address gentile, and Shape becoming. But you are still finding fault with what you have not wit to understand.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Am I so, Madam? and I am now your Aversion, for abusing this Stranger. Could you in agi●e your Cunning laid so deep, that one of your own Sex could not see through it? All the harm I wish is your Indian may prove half so taking. But I have done, and here comes one will plague you enough on that Subject. Exit Flora.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p: I warrant you Girls have been talking of a Husband, and I can't blame you. I made my Wife confess she thought of nothing else.— That Look won't doe, Vil.— I know it longs, and so forth. Come, come, your Mother tells me you're a Woman, and so forth.— That's enough, Vil,—

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: We had Discourse that was much more serious, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p: Nay, by my troth, Vil. thou art fit to be married now thou canst dissemble so well.— But do'st thou know, Girl, he's coming?— hah— does it not move, affect, and so forth?— A word to the wise, Vil.—

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Sir, I know nothing but my Duty.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p: That's right, take the India's then. Oh, if he be like his Father— Vil.— I'll say no more. But for a sparkling Eye and Wit, we were the same, and carried it; knew all the Poets and Players, and writ Prologues; nay, I had once the credit to be nam'd for a Lampoon. Time is, time was, Vil.
Here 'tis, Vil.— [Shews a Letter.] Each minute I expect him, and shall take it ill not to see a young Vitelli in a twelvemonth.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: I hope, Sir, it will be no breach of Duty to ask some time to consider.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p: Consider?— why, thy Mother and I were smitten, bargain'd, and so forth, before you could pluck up a Veil.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: I must not be accounted disobedient; but yet—

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p: Nay, that Toy of Modesty becomes thee, &c. but I'm your Father, Vil. and though merry, know what's what, Vil.— I give you leave to make up your mouth, &c.— But when he comes, expect a Curtesie, and, I thank you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: What a curst thing is this not to have my Q— Aside. Sir, here's a Gentleman would speak with you.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p: Has he no name, and so forth?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I never saw him, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p: Retire, Daughter.— If it be the man you wot of, go in and twitter, you shall be call'd.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Whatever this Stranger means, I wish he had all my Bribe to be fairly rid of him. Exeunt Viol. Flo.

div.stage: Enter Peralta, Fabio with the Portmantue.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Your right leg foremost, Sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Sir, when I tell you I am Don Pedro Vitelli, and come from India, I hope I may beg a Welcome; this I know, my Father gave me some assurance of it.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p: Don Pedro Vitelli must challenge Welcome as long as I am Don Gomez, &c. And how does the good Gonzalo, my old Friend, your Father? Thou mak'st me weep for joy. Just such was he, when we began our first Acquaintance.— I should have known thee in the Street, thou art so like, the very shape and face, &c.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I was always thought like him, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Yes, as a Bear's an Elephant. The Old man's as fond of the Cheat as my Master of the Wench. Aside.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: This Letter I was commanded to deliver from my Father, with Thanks for the great Honour you design'd his Son.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p: Honest man!— Yes, yes, this is the old Hand and Style to a very tittle. He reads.
You are doubly welcome—. Let me embrace you: my Joys are so compleat, I scarcely can contain my self. Embraces him.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Not so hard; he's weak in the back since the last Cure.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p: He tells me he had once thought to come with these Gallions; but then I had been too happy.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, he did, but some unexpected Business has deferr'd his purpose till their next return. In the mean time, Sir, he has sent me as a Pledge and Token of his ancient Friendship.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p: And trust me, a welcome one. Nay, my Daughter shall tell you so too— Flora.— By Saint Isidor I was so overjoy'd to see you, I had forgot to give her notice of your Arrival.
Tell Vil. the happy Minute's coming, bid her put on her best Looks, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Sir, I beg you would let this be disposed of in your Closet, about twelve thousand Ducats in Gold and Jewels, what I could bring conveniently from Cadiz; the rest will be sent.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p: I'll be your faithfull Steward. Flora, shew the way where it may be laid, and hasten your Mistress.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: [To Fabio.] Come, Sir, if you dare follow.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: I never refus'd a Challenge from a Woman.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p: Fie, fie, this Girl makes me out of patience.—

Oh here she comes.— Come hither, Vil. this is he; Look and like, Vil. 'tis thy Father's Choice, and a wise one, though I say it.— I know you young people have some fine things to say to one another, &c. therefore I'll leave you, and talk a while with your Man about the Affairs of the New World and the like. Fabio returns.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: He will be able to say something, though you can expect no perfect account from one of his Breeding:— at leisure I shall satisfie you, Sir. Gomez and Fabio at a distance.

Now, Madam, I hope you will allow me more Freedom then when
you cruelly shunn'd my Addresses; and one that leaves the world he was born in, meerly to serve you, may justly expect some kind of Welcome.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: This Encounter is more strange then the former: and I can scarce imagine, the man that took so long a Journey for a particular Mistress, would make so zealous a Court to the first he meets. The Lady in the Veil has the promise of that Heart to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: And to mine too, Madam, or else this deceives me— Shews the Picture. Could you imagine one that had spent a year in Contemplation should not know you at the first glaunce?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: And yet you brib'd my Maid to learn my Name.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: True, onely to take an opportunity of giving something to one I knew I must be beholden to.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Your Trial of me was not too kind, Sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I confess, Madam, there's something extravagant in what's past: but I hope Curiosity and your Goodness will excuse it— Nor was it fit I own'd my self, till I could produce such Letters and Treasure as might secure me from being thought an Impostour for the future.—

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, my old Master studies night and day: he is just now writing a Book, and intends to dedicate it to you.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p: Then he has outstript me; I could never arrive farther then a Madrigal, &c.— And how is Mexico to Madrid?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Catch me at Descriptions, and I'll hang for't. Aside.
What's more wonderful then any thing in the Old or New World, he is a great Poet, and yet vastly rich.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p: What kind of Court does the Vice-roy keep? is the Palace magnificent?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: 'Faith, Sir, I think I may venture to tell you, 'tis whisper'd my old Master knows no end of his Wealth.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p: Are the Streets large and fair? what garb do the Indians keep? &c.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: My young Master, Sir, may be worth— let me see— a million of Ducats; and when his Father dies—

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p: This Fellow's mind is all on Money: a shallow Rascal.— But these Answers are to my purpose: for if he be Rich, &c. let the Woman run the rest of the Hazard, and the New World be as 'twill.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: I am sure I have kept to windward of the Law, let my Master look to the upshot.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p: This I like, this looks as Man and Wife; and may ye be as happy, &c. as Gonzalo and I can wish you. To Peralta.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Sir, there can be nothing less then Happiness accompany the Possessour of so much Goodness. And if she think me worthy of her, I must go into a Third World, to learn something new to wish to make me more blessed.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p: See you there, Vil. that's a Flight: many one of them, and such like, have I had in my Youth. Old Gonzalo still!— Well, Son, your Father and I were Wags, &c. in our young days.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Each thing you say reminds me so much of him, that were not I thus doubly blest, I should think of Mexico.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p: Well, Vil. for a Man and Wealth thou art fitted; and she that looks for more must die, &c. This World I'm sure affords nothing— Come, Son, we'll go in, you're weary, and I long to discourse you: for this Man of your's is none of the great Intelligencers. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: 'Tis ten to one but we shall play the old Romantick trick, and while the Knight and Lady are at work, the Squire and Damsel imitate.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I shall like you well enough, if you have another Romantick trick too, of drowning or hanging your self, if you see me displeas'd. For the truth is, you have a Face I would fain be rid of. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
Not so willingly as I would free my self of this House.— What a-Devil can come of a thing built upon a Quicksand? This they may call Love and Adventures: but he that can foresee a good End of them need never despair at the Gallows. But so it is—
When for a Wench our Voiage is design'd,
We boldly sail against both Tide and Wind. Exit.

div.trailer: The End of the Second ACT.

div.head: ACT III.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: ON my life, Sir, 'tis he; the very Vitelli whose Portmantue we hav— I see him with Don Gomez.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Curst Fortune! in the very minute? two Hours had possest me of her.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: What do you think of a fair and honourable Retreat?— This is the way out.—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Dog! I'll think of nothing but Victory; and will be, and am Vitelli, Son to Gonzalo. Think me any thing else, and I ll cut thy throat.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: You may be what you please: but I hope you'll allow me still to be Fabio, and to think my self in great Danger. I know it nothing concerns you.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Coward! no Flinching; but follow my Example, and lie like thy self, we will still carry it. In the mean while let's retire, and contrive to meet the worst.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: There needs no great Contrivance, it will meet us.— For my part, I'll lurk hereabouts for Intelligence. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p: But, prithee Friend, have I so silly a Face, and so forth, that you could pick no body else out so fit to put a Cheat on? Good faith you're deceiv'd in old Gomez, he understands Trap, &c.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: I cannot yet understand why you mistrust me; I'm sure I expected such another Welcome from one I lookt upon as Father.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p: I'll say that for thee, thou'rt a pleasant Fellow, and hast as lucky a Countenance to conceal a Cheat as one would wish to purchase. But this is a little too gross— and how came we to be so nigh of kin?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: The Respect I bear you keeps me from taking any thing ill; nor can you by the worst of words force me into a Passion with the Father of Violante, whom Gonzalo made me believe I should at my arrival from the Indies call Life.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p:
And so you shall, if you can lay any just Claim. But you ●ay with the same Confidence pretend to the Kingdom of Spain, &c.
and with much the same Success, believe me— Violante?— ha, ha, ha.—

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: That you are Don Gomez you your self assure me, nor am I less Don Vitelli. That Violante is your Daughter you own, and Gonzalo your Friend, for whose Son you have design'd her. Why then does all I say seem Riddle? Is it the custom of Spain to mock those they style Friends? if so, the Indians are much less barbarous.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p: The Devil take me, and so forth, if this Fellow have not a pretty wheadling confident way with him. I'll confound him a little.—
Well, Sir, since you will be Vitelli, I know you have often heard your Father speak of me, and how we spent our time when young.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: No day, Sir, but your Friendship is his subject; and this he bids me imitate. Tells how you vied in Arms and Arts; often wishes (though blest with Wealth) he had never left Spain, but still enjoy'd your Company.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p: Very fine.— I'm much beholden to him, &c. Did he never enter into particulars of our Affairs?

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: Yes, I've heard him say, when Fellow-students, you had one Purse; that the same Books, the same Company pleas'd you: and that your Fancies kept so even pace, that you often joyn'd upon the same Subject without the difference of the Style perceiv'd.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p: I wish this Fellow's Shoes were off, that I might see whether he has cloven Feet or no. How could he possibly know this else? Of what Age, what Stature and Complexion is he?

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: In all agreeable to you, and what he says so like your way of Speech, that sure I must call you Father. One think remarkable and private too is a Star on his right Side, by a Wound receiv'd in a Duel wherein he was your Second: and you, Sir, as he told me, was then run through the Thigh, being on the same day you should have married.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p: This Truth startles me. Aside.
Do you know to whom?

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, Donna Beatriz Cruz●d●, whom you first saw at Saint Isidor's Church, and that a month after your Marriage was consummate.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p: 'Tis a clear case, I am not Gomez, nor this my House, nor he within Vitelli; no, no, all's a downright Mistake.— Friend, dost thou know whether there be two Gonzalo's, and two Vitelli's, that love and know by Sympathy? or art not thou something of a Spirit, and so forth? ha?

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: The Gentleman's distracted. Aside:
Sir, this I know, that I am the man I pretend to be, and grieve to find you thus.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p:
Where you pick up these Truths, is beyond my power to guess● but. I can demonstrate you false and counterfeit. For if true, where
the Jewels, and so forth, you wrote you would bring with you? shew my Daughter's Picture I sent, your Father's Letters, and all that.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: That's my Misfortune; this very morning I was robb'd of all: but if you will have patience to wait—

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p: This I knew would tickle you. Let old Gomez alone to find out a Cheat, and so forth. Stole from you? yes by the right Owner, who brought them to me.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: To convince you, I know to a Rial what's in the Portmantue, each particular Jewel and Paper.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p: This is some Confidence of another World, and almost distracts me.— Within, call Don Vitelli.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: Use not my Name to such a Villain; for so I dare pronounce and justifie him.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Ne'r fear, I have over-heard all, and can help you in a stress.— To Peralta entring.
Don Fernando, Sir. Aloud.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: This is argument of great Kindness, to make such haste from Cadiz to be at the Wedding of your Friend. Welcome, dear Fernando; for so I dare bid you to the House of him has given me leave to call him Father.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p: New Riddles still!

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: Steel'd Impudence!— how canst thou with confidence pronounce so damn'd a Forgery?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: We got well hither with our Treasure, to which I believe your good Wishes contributed.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: Slave, the Place secures thee.—

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p: You're acquainted then, and so forth.—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: The onely Friend I had in Mexico; we were Neighbours, School-fellows, and in the same Ship arriv'd at Spain: nor can any one give you a more perfect account of my Father or his Affairs; for I know nothing I have conceal'd from him.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p: He has hardly used you like a Friend, without Cheat, Villain, &c. are signs of Love amongst you.— Nay, with Confidence he endeavour'd to face me out he was the true Vitelli.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: And with the same honest Assurance stand here to make it good.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: This is like thee, always driving on some piece of Extravagance.— But trust me, Fernando, this is so unseasonable, as to break our Friendship, if persisted in.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: I scorn thee, am, and always was a Stranger to thy Friendship; and here pronounce thee Cheat, Thief, Murtherer. Beware, Old man, you warm a Snake will leave a fatal Sting.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Could I believe you were in earnest, I should be angry, Sir; but for this once forgive.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: I demand nothing but Justice, and by Heaven will have it.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p: What can he design by all this?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Why, Sir, you have had experience enough to know the World's wicked, and Love powerful.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p: Yes it is, always was, and always will be, &c.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: I have had long a Jealousie that he was not right. For when my Master produc'd his Jewels, and shew'd his Treasure, he would so eye and sigh; and at the Picture cast such wanton amorous Glances, that I fear that's the true ground of his haste from Cadiz, thinking to prevent us. Then I minded he catcht at each Story that might seem very particular; as one my Master was the other day telling of a Duel, and a Wound you received in the Thigh. Nay, he was so inquisitive, that he would count the Money and Jewells.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p: I have no Doubt left; there 'tis I warrant. This Devil of Love invents more Tricks then a Iew ready to starve.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Then, Sir, he has a plaguy wheadling Tongue, and such a set Look, that he was made to deceive.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p: So he has, and by my troth had deceiv'd me, if he had come first. But bless my Stars, &c. that shall suddenly be prevented.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: If nothing will do, from henceforth you are my Enemy, and as such I shall next meet you.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: Dare but quit this House, and no other Sanctuary shall protect thee.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p: Desperate Villain, be gone, &c. or else an Alguazil shall provide you a Lodging.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: Was ever Age thus blinded? Stay but my returns from Cadiz before you conclude.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p: No, this very night shall consummate the Match with the Noble Vitelli.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: No, Don Gomez, you throw her away upon a base Deluder; who is indeed a Souldier of Flanders, fled hither to gain a Pardon for Murther.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p: This sounds like Forgery. You have no choice, but quit the House, or to Prison.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: See how wild his Story is, and how quick Passion makes his Invention. Be gone, or this shall force it.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: I'll go, because my being confin'd will render me absolutely uncapable of Remedy.— But I shall expect you have so much Honour left as to meet me in the Prado.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I will, and with my Sword chastise this Insolence. An hour hence let it be.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: Agreed. But I shall scarce fight such a Rogue, till I have secur'd my Mistress. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p:
Well, Son, this Adventure is so extraordinary, that were
your Father and I as when time was, the Players should not have wanted a Comedy, nor an Audience, &c. though I say it.— What, melancholick?—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: You must give me leave to reflect a little on the Loss of one I thought my Friend, nay doted on, and would have yielded all things up to satisfie his very Curiosity, but Violante.—

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p: Come, an ●ll thing's better lost then found: the World grows worse and worse, &c.
You have reason to be satisfied, you have so timely found his Falshood.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Let me beg you would urge that; for no man loves with such Truth, nor no man grieves with such Sincerity.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p: For shame, Son, I shall think you repent your Voiage. Let's in, and my Daughter will make amends with true Affection.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: The name of such a Remedy makes me forget my Disease; and she is now my onely Friend, as well as Mistress.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Bating some odd hundreds, and so forth.
sp.stage: Enter Flora going over as in haste.
sp.p: [To her.] You can never be in such haste as to refuse the profers of a sincere Lover.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: The very name of Love from one I hate adds wings to me.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Not so fierce, good Damsell; though I have no Portmantue of Jewells, I have some Treasure about me I brought from the Indies, you'll like much better.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I warrant some petty Shells and Baubles, things I scorn as much as I do you. My Mistress were miserably provided, were the Master and Valet alike.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Come, mine Sentences are not for people of our quality. To have and to hold's the word; and the licking of the Posset-bason when they have done will save charges, and yet look Princely.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: No, Valet, next to you I hate nothing more then what has been pall'd.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Except a Petticoat, and that of sixteen removes; yet must be thought to look new, like the Chambermaid after being paum'd by the whole Family.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Still fresher then a Suit that after three generations in the Indies must be new turn'd for the Wedding.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Come, 'faith never deny't, if thou hast pawn'd thy Utensils for Lees of wine and Chippings, or art contracted for Gizzards, and the fifth quarter of a Hen call'd the Guts, I desist: otherwise, which is the top of your Hopes, I offer you Flesh unblown, Fabio the sound and trusty.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p:
To convince you of my Aversion, I had rather live a wrinkled
Maid of sixty, and then be burnt for a Witch, then have any thing to doe with thee.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: This looks so like the Courtship of our Form, that it is no less then an evident token of Love— which thus I seal.—

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: And thus I deliver.—

div.stage: Gives him a box on the ear, and runs out.

sp.speaker: Elv. to Clara.
sp.p: I Am now resolv'd; therefore without disputing about what I commanded you.— Exit Clara.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: I have told you all in short; and he that is more miserable must meet something yet unknown. To be outfac'd, rejected for a Villain, tied up by Nicety and Respect from Revenge, without a prospect of retrieving my Right, is what the most patient must want temper to bear.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Wherein I can serve you, you may with assurance command, and I am apt at present not to think my self altogether incapable.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: I dare promise my self any thing from so noble a Succour.— Bless me therefore with something like Hope.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: The means how, I beg you will not inquire into; but I have some reason to be confident of a Design will defer the Marriage till you can hear from Cadiz: whither I advise you would immediately send post.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: This would secure my Happiness, and a little time gain'd certainly discover the Cheat.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: To prevent all Danger, if he comes out according to appointment to fight you, prepare Alguazills to seize him for the Robbery. It cannot be dishonourable thus to treat so base a man, and vindicate your self. Before he can procure his Liberty, your Post will be returned, and all be clear'd. This requires dispatch, therefore haste; within half an hour I'll meet you.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: I have just reason to suspect him too false to keep his word; my greatest confidence is your Conduct. Exit.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p:
What this will come to, is as impossible to guess, as that it could ever come to this. But I'll in, and hasten Clara.—
Once on the Ground, I can no lower fall:
And venture nothing, though I venture all. Exit.

div.head: SCENE 3. The High Street.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: SInce you have reason to despair of finding one in a Crowd, whose person you have no knowledge of, make this Tumult a Diversion; at least defer these melancholick Thoughts. Thou art now something more extravagant then Love could make thee. Nay, would I curse a man, I'd wish him as nice a sense of Honour as Antonio.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I know my self to blame: but all I see of this great Preparation has so much unaccountable, taudry Gallantry in it, is so far from what I think, that to me Sickness would prove greater Pleasure then that the rest of men seem fond of. Carlos, I am not what I was; all my Ambition, Dotage of youth and Beauty, make but one intire thought of Hatred and Revenge: and could I satisfie this Passion, I should die with more delight then assured Martyrs suffer.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: In earnest, Antonio—

div.stage: Enter Clara half veiled, in Womens cloaths, who seeing them pulls it over her Face.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Ha! that Face I have seen.—

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Now cannot I move a step; my masculine Spirit with my Habit leaves me. I have nothing but my Woman's Cunning to trust to.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Tis she, Carlos; the very Clara, Pimp and Confident to Elvira.— Baud!— Antonio goes to Clara.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: You cannot think your self in Spain, or that you talk to one of Quality, to treat me thus. Nor could any thing but your Mistake of the person perswade me to forgive this Insolence.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Impudent Strumpet! would I had ne'r had cause to know thee. Unveil, or I'll tear it and thee to pieces.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Stranger, you'll repent this horrid Rudeness. Know, people of my Rank cannot want Revengers of their Honour.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What do you mean, Antonio? 'tis dangerous to force a Veil in Court: you may mistake.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I tell thee she's my Sister's foul Associate, and Seller of her Honour.— Discover, or by my Father's soul—

div.stage: Antonio lays hold of his Dagger.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Hold, Sir; 'tis I.—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Base Devil! thou shouldst not live, were it not to tell me where Elvira is.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Be moderate, Antonio, your Threats will fright her from the Truth.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: That, Sir, Heaven be my witness, I am as ignorant of as those that ne'r saw light.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Confess, or each minute shall invent new Punishment to rack it from thee. Thus with little Tortures I'll begin— and let out some of thy loose Bloud.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: This is a Transport unworthy of thee.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Should I trust a Rock I have already split on? Confess, or by—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Be not so cruel, and I'll tell you all.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Give her time to think, Antonio; this Encounter may prove most lucky.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: But this time, dear Invention! and let me die a Fool.—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: About it then, and I will be patient.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: That fatal night we left your House, I waited on her to the Convent of Molbietro, where your Aunt is Abbess; who entertain'd her with no small Grief, when inform'd of the Accident that drove her to that Sanctuary; whence she dispatcht me to this place in search of her false Vitelli.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Of Hell, then which this Lie is falser.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: To me this Story seems probable.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: So Heaven and you afford me Mercy as 'tis true.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: When came you hither?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Not three hours since I alighted in this Inn, where I found—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Whom?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Vitelli.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Vitelli here? Oh let me fly to my Revenge! On, good Clara. I can almost forgive thee.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: As I came out, he left his Chamber in search of a Servant he is sending out of Town, and cannot be far off.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: If this prove true—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Why should you suspect me false, when 'tis my Lady's intorest you should find him? But to leave no Scruple, I'll conduct you to his Chamber, and produce unquestionable Testimonies. This you must remember, it is no longer Vitelli you pursue.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: More tricks yet? who then?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: What I shall discover will convince you. 'Tis Peralta, a Captain fled from Flanders for a Murther, and took Valentia in his way. All this I learnt from Papers of his left in his Chamber, which I thought I was bound to search, when I knew they belong'd to him; that I might give a good account to her that sent me.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: This news is beyond our expectation or hope.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Tis what I'll improve to his certain Ruine.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: First by fair means (which you have often promised me, if he was a Gentleman) you must retrieve her Credit, by offering him to marry her. They whisper.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Indian, you must pardon me, since to secure my Mistress, her Lover and my self, I expose you to the first shock of Antonio's Rage: and good faith, Charity begins at home.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Come along, and direct us to this Chamber of Discovery.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: This way, Sir.— Can I but get clear of you, and give my Lady timely notice,— discover what you can.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
I must preserve Peralta, if possible, for the fair Elvira's Safety:
For that depends on his, and if He dies,
She too must fall nice Honour's Sacrifice. Exeunt.

div.trailer: The End of the Third ACT.

div.head: ACT IV. SCENE 1. The Inn-Yard.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: THe Horses are ready, Sir.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: Take this then, [Gives him a Letter,] and shew your Kindness to your Master by your quick Return.— One thing more.

div.stage: While Vitelli whispers to Crispin, Enter Antonio, Carlos, Clara.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: This looks like truth.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: For more certainty see where he stands. Points to Vitelli.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Is that my Enemy?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: That's Vitelli, or Peralta, which you please, or both.— I hope this Shift may free me, and I'll still about the dispatch of my Message. Aside.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Your Name's Peralta, Sir?

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: I neither own the Name nor Temper of that curst Villain. What I really am I dare speak, which is, Don Vitelli.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Thou'rt a Villain under both Names, and as such I'll use you.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: I can scarce think my self born of a Spaniard, to meet such Rudeness as my nature perfectly abhors.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Damn your Sentences— and know your Forgeries and you are discover'd.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: To none that dare name my Actions so, and know me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yes, Villain, Elvira's Wrongs and mine shall proclaim them And if thou hast so much Valour to defend thy self against the Brother, as Cunning to betray a wretched Woman, draw, and know 'tis Antonio heightned with a just Revenge that bids thee.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: This world is all Madness and Mistake.— Could I but think you were not deceiv'd in the Person, and had not too good reason to know the true Peralta deserves all this, I should not thus tamely dispute the Wrong.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
What, Coward too? and think to conquer me as my lost Sister
by Words?— Draw, or by Heaven I'll doe the act of Justice, and rid the world of a perjur'd Slave.—

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: Provok'd thus, I must be more, or much less then Man to suffer. They draw.

div.stage: Carlos with his Sword interposes to part them.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: What will this come to?— Those Officers at the gate shall determine the Quarrel. Clara runs out.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Friendship's a Name, Carlos, when it stands in competition with Honour and Revenge.— What, must Antonio live and see (good Heavens!) the Ravisher of his Sister safe?— By all—

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What I urge is your Promise, and her Honour. And if he will make up this Breach by Marriage, you create a new Enemy to refuse so just Terms.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: Little Hecks! do you think with a seeming Quarrel to force me to the keeping of a Whore, and take off your stale Goods? No, shew your selves for Cheats, and both assault me; whilst the innocent Vitelli dares thus undauntedly oppose you.

div.stage: Enter Clara with Officers. She points to Vitelli.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: That's he,— seize him. And at your own peril be his escape.— I have too much kindness for Vitelli, to let him perish for Peralta: a little Confinement will break no squares. The Officers seize Vitelli.

sp.speaker: 1. Offic.
sp.p: Seiz'd by us the Devil can't escape.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: More Complices? Thieves! Murtherers! lose me, or—

sp.speaker: 2. Offic.
sp.p: No, Sir, Murtherer falls upon your own head, and 'tis the Ensign's bloud you shed in Flanders that calls for Vengeance.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Let him at liberty, and I'll revenge it bravely, and save the dull Ceremonies of Law.

sp.speaker: 1. Offic.
sp.p: You owe us Thanks that you are not confin'd; this Quarrel deserves it.

sp.speaker: 2. Offic.
sp.p: If you consult your own Safeties, away.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Come, Antonio, you must know the Town too well, not to understand a Retreat necessary in this case. Antonio, Carlos retire.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: What can you mean, Gentlemen? I ne'r saw Flanders nor Spain till this last Flota from the Indies●

sp.speaker: 1. Offic.
sp.p: This won't do, Sir, we are told of Writings in your Chamber will convince you, whither we intend to carry you, and thence to Prison.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.p: Curst Peralta! now thou hast secur'd thy Designs. Gentlemen, I hope I may beg leave to speak with a Knight of Malta in the house before my Confinement.

sp.speaker: 1. Offic.
sp.p: No, Sir, we must and will prevent a Rescue: onely take your Papers with us, and then secure you.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: What means this Disturbance in my House?

sp.speaker: 2. Offic.
sp.p: Onely the Seizure of one Peralta for a Murther.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Peralta? this will be sad news to Don Luis.— Aside. I'll be his Bail.

sp.speaker: 1. Offic.
sp.p: The Crime admits of none; along, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: The Widow has been too cunning for us; and that Don Luis must speedily understand. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: CLara escap'd, and Peralta secur'd from my Sword? something must and shall be done. Nor is it fit the Law punish a single Murther, whilst mine and my Sister's Honours remain unrevenged. I'll arm him my self, and in his own Chamber fairly kill him.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Yes, and suffer in his stead, while milder means may dompass your Designs. And if Antonio dare trust me—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Trust thee, Carlos? yes, with Life, with Honour, All, I freely do. I find I am not fit to guide my self. Henceforth thy settled Judgement gives me Laws; but still remember my Sister's Wrongs, and where Peralta is.— Oh that Name!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Pray, no more, your hasty Rage has already prov'd Clara's loss, whose recovery will be necessary to our Affairs. She cannot yet be far; therefore let us round this Street: half an hour hence I'll visit the Prisoner, and doubt not to get more by Fair words and Promises, then your Sword could extort.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Should he accept your Offer, the cause of his Imprisonment brings his certain Ruine with my Infamy.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: There's no danger on that side: a sum of Money prevents the Prosecution, and gains his Liberty. For 'tis as great a Miracle for a Rich man to be hang'd, as a Poor man to scape. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE 3. Chamber in the Inn.
div.stage: Elvira in Womens cloaths, Clara very rich.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I Am much too miserable e're to hope to make thee amends.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: You make your self so with fine Speeches. Let me learn you what Dangers Resolution and Cunning may avoid. Think now of nothing but a fit Story to wheadle old Gomez, who will instantly be here.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Had I but thy Courage, I could not faile but as I am, something thrills through my Bloud, and makes me tremble. How can I think to impose upon him with a false Story, who so steadily repuls'd Vitelli's true one?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: And so easily believ'd Peralta's, that was as false as yours. I tell you, Madam, he has a believing Countena●ce● and looks like one of our politick News-mongers, who are sure to entertain a Story for being strange, and of themselves find out Reasons to make it probable, then conclude it true.
